title.value: Investigating the neural correlates of affective mentalizing and their association with general intelligence in patients with schizophrenia
title.justification: This is the exact title from the provided research paper.
title.quote: Investigating the neural correlates of affective mentalizing and their association with general intelligence in patients with schizophrenia.

extractions.description: This paper aims to replicate previous findings regarding the neural correlates of affective mentalizing in patients with schizophrenia and investigate its possible association with impaired domain-general cognition, particularly verbal intelligence. The study involved functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and cognitive assessments on patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls from German and Australian cohorts.

type.justification: The paper involves experimentation and data collection through fMRI and cognitive assessments to gather evidence.
type.quote: We analyzed imaging data from two large multi-centric German studies including 64 patients, 64 matched controls and a separate cohort of 300 healthy subjects, as well as an independent Australian study including 64 patients and 46 controls.

name.justification: The paper is focused on the study of brain function and neural correlates using fMRI.
name.quote: This study aimed to replicate previous findings of aberrant activation of the mentalizing network in schizophrenia and investigate its possible association with impaired domain-general cognition.

name.justification: The study focuses on mentalizing and cognitive impairments in patients with schizophrenia, which are key issues in the field of mental health.
name.quote: Mentalizing impairment in schizophrenia has been linked to aberrant neural responses.

name.justification: The study involves investigating the Theory of Mind (ToM) network and its activations.
name.quote: Theory of Mind (ToM) or mentalizing refers to the ability to entertain and manipulate representations of othersâ€™ mental states such as beliefs, intentions, or emotions.

name.justification: The study investigates the association between affective mentalizing and domain-general cognitive functions such as verbal intelligence.
name.quote: Deficits in non-social cognition are well documented in SZ, and some evidence indicates that domain-general cognitive function rather than a specialized social-cognitive process influences ToM-performance in both healthy subjects and SZ patients.
